subject: Newbie Questions: Utility, Reality, and Inevitability

messageBody:
Hello all. This is long {winded} email on (I think) a new topic.

I joined this group a few days ago and have spent a bit of time
reading most of the messages since 2k1 (yes, my eyes are tired). I've
also taken a look at the posted files. I must say that I admire the
work you've all done in pushing Quickscript into the 21st Century.

A bit about me; I've been in the workplace over 30 years doing
various things. Most recently I claim the dubious role of software
industry drone with a background in web, database, and application
programming, localization, as well as software and hardware technical
writing. I have university degrees in Creative Writing and Library
Science, for what they are worth.

For decades I've kept a diary -- first on paper, then using key entry
on computer, then using palm pilot graffiti. For the past 18 months,
due to my work requirements, I've used a combination of a tablet pc
(cursive) and Windows mobile phone pc (again, using graffiti).
Needless to say, I sync heavily between them.

Since I first started using graffiti 8 years ago, I recognized the
utility that a true shorthand-base input system would provide to me
in my personal writings. Going from paper to keyboard was a leap
forward as far as efficiency was concerned (I type a casual 40-60 wpm
on my best days); however going from keyboard to graffiti was a step
back -- even when incorporating predictive dictionaries, my input is
pretty slow, requiring a significant time invenstment (there is a
chair in a certain pub nicknamed the 'Tungsten' chair, since I sat
there at length many nights journalling on my Palm Pilot and tipping
pints).

Up to this point, I made no move to invest time in learning any
shorthand. What was the point? I'd have to transcribe it by hand
anyway.

Now, with the tablet pc's incredibly sophisticated ability to
recognize cursive (it was able to recognize my rather sloppy
handwriting and render into English (US) with *no* training) my dream
of being able to write in shorthand and have on-demand conversion to
text (on not -- as some have pointed out here, shorthand is currently
as good as encryption for the 90% case) is close to reality. The work
being done here on fonts and Unicode is the last piece of the puzzle.
Bravo!

In recent weeks my workload has lightened a bit I've been able to
spend some time researching viable shorthand systems, with the
inevitable discovery of Quickscript. It satisfies my personal and
selfish requirements of being an effective, logical, sensible, and
learnable system.

If you've read this far, congratulations, I'm finally getting to the
my questions.

1. My anticipated model of usage (once I'm competent in Quickscript)
is as follows:
a. Write in Quickscript on either my tablet or mobile pc.
b. Convert to my electronic locale of choice (English (US)) if
I so choose.
c. I will never assume that anyone will ever read my raw notes.
If I want to share something, it will be as a conversion.

Is this a reasonable model of usage?

2. Given the above, I'd say that I'm intending to use Quickscript as
a personal tool. When sharing, I'll use standard spelling as (for
lack of a better term) an *escrita franca*, which any literate
English speaker will understand over time, since locale-based
(especially pronunciative) differences are greatly reduced. Since I'm
indifferent to anyone understanding my raw notes, questions about how
to use, say, 'air' <I say err> or 'array' <I say uh-ray> are moot; in
the case of the relatively few gray instances I've seen discussed in
this group I'll simply pick a usage that makes sense to me, stick
with it, and adjust my pc to do a custom correction/conversion in
those cases.

Is this an unreasonable expectation to set for myself? I don't have
any qualms at spending a year or two becoming proficient in a
slightly personalized Quickscript, and in so doing departing from a
proposed universal standard: I'm just like that (for instance, I use
a variant of the US-Dvorak keyboard that I've designed to accommodate
my own typing quirks).

3. And this, a comment. Given #2, my model actually becomes:

a. Write in a slightly customized Quickscript on either my
tablet or mobile pc.
b. Convert to my electronic locale of choice (English (US)) if
I so choose.
c. Apply customization to the result, since availble converters
will likely adhere to the standard being developed by members
of this group. (Or write a custom converter).
c. I will still never assume that anyone will ever read my raw
notes. If I want to share something, it will be as a conversion.

I'm thinking this model, without an intelligent (or locale-based)
converter, is too much to ask the typical prospective Quicksort user
of the future.


That's all for now. I'm interested in thoughts about any one of these
items. As always, trim the response -- this email of mine has become
bloated beyond belief.

thanks
scribbleodd
